explanatory comments/crosstagging: Interestingly, a photo-realistic handshake (depicting female hands) is drawn on this card titled “Oversea Greetings” [...]. Apparently, in the early 20th century, picture postcards were also printed on sailing ships and distributed to the travellers as a goodwill gesture. (Yousuf Saeed) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Although this one has been printed in England by J.Beagles & Co., it was posted by one Ms. Shanky on November 27th, 1911 addressed to one Harry P. Otig, a loco foreman at Aligarh junction in north India, but seems to have a postmark (dated 15 December 1911) of Tuticorin, a port town in Tamil Nadu, where many ships sailing across the Indian Ocean halted briefly. The icons of handshake and sailing ship have been readily adapted in many early Eid cards. (Yousuf Saeed)(gs)
